contentrichtext.text: {{Japanese city |Name = Onagawa |JapaneseName = 女川町 |settlement_type= Town |MapImage= Onagawa in Miyagi Prefecture Ja.svg |Region = [[Tōhoku Region|Tōhoku]] |Prefecture = [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]] |District= [[Oshika District, Miyagi|Oshika]] |Area_km2 = 65.78 |Population = 11,186 |PopDate = 2003 |Density_km2 = auto |Mayor = |Coords= |LatitudeDegrees = 38 |LatitudeMinutes = 26 |LatitudeSeconds = 17 |LongtitudeDegrees = 141 |LongtitudeMinutes = 27 |LongtitudeSeconds = 00 |Elevation = |Tree = |Flower = |Bird = |SymbolImage= Flag of Onagawa, Miyagi.svg |CityHallPostalCode = |CityHallAddress= |CityHallPhone= |CityHallLink = [http://www.town.onagawa.miyagi.jp/ Town of Onagawa] }} {{nihongo|'''Onagawa'''|女川町|Onagawa-chō}} is a [[towns of Japan|town]] located in [[Oshika District, Miyagi]], [[Japan]]. The town was formed in 1926. The town takes pride in the fact that it still has beaches with "[[Singing sand|squeaking sand]]", which has apparently become rare in Japan due to human induced environmental changes.<ref>[http://www.town.onagawa.miyagi.jp/maintop_eng.html ONAGAWA Town Homepage<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Onagawa is a port town, and right at the intersection of two major ocean currents. It is also the location of a nuclear power plant, the [[Onagawa Nuclear Power Plant]]. As of 2003, the town has an estimated [[population]] of 11,186 and a [[population density]] of 170.05 persons per km². The total area is 65.78 km². ==2011 earthquake and tsunami== [[File:Carried cars.JPG|thumb|right|Onagawa after the tsunami]] The town was heavily damaged in the 11 March [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. The tsunami reached {{convert|15|m}} in height and swept {{convert|1|km}} inland, destroying the town centre and leaving over 1000 people missing, with over 300 confirmed dead.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110404a5.html India rescue team pitches in], ''[[Japan Times]]'' 4 April 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?EQ_0=5413&t=101650&s=9&d=92,183&nd=display NOAA Data]</ref> At least 12 of the town's 25 designated evacuation sites were inundated by the tsunami. The city had previously been hit and partially destroyed by the tsunami caused by [[1960 Valdivia earthquake]].<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110414a4.html Tsunami hit more than 100 designated evacuation sites]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 14 April 2011, p. 1.</ref> In an incident widely reported in the Chinese media, Mitsuru Sato, managing director of Sato Suisan, a fish processing company in the town, gave his life ensuring that all the firm's workers, including 20 female Chinese resident trainees, had evacuated safely to higher ground.<ref>Pulvers, Roger, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110327rp.html Japan's crises spark wide alarm and some unlikely sympathizers]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 27 March 2011, p. 8.</ref> ==Transport== The town has a ferry service to the sacred island of [[Kinkasan]]. ===Railway stations=== * [[Ishinomaki Line]]: [[Urashuku Station|Urashuku]] - [[Onagawa Station|Onagawa]] ===Ferry Terminal=== *[[Kinkasan]] *Enoshima, via Izushima ===Major roads=== * [[Route 398 (Japan)|Route 398]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline}} *{{cite journal|last=Phelan|first=Stephen|title=Washed Away|journal=Boston Review|year=2013|month=MARCH/APRIL|url=http://www.bostonreview.net/BR38.2/stephen_phelan_japan_tsunami_anniversary.php}} * [http://www.town.onagawa.miyagi.jp Onagawa official website] {{ja icon}} [[Category:Towns in Miyagi Prefecture]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1926]] {{Miyagi-geo-stub}}
